H0.text: Selective breeding is the process that helps dairy farmers develop cows that produce greater amounts of milk than average cows.

H1.text: Behavioral modification is the process that will help dairy farmers develop cows that produce greater amounts of milk than average cows.

H2.text: Ecological succession is the process that helps dairy farmers develop cows that produce greater amounts of milk than average cows.

H3.text: Geographical isolation is a process that helps dairy farmers develop cows with greater milk production than average cows.

A4.text: Selective breeding can lead to a variety of issues including reduction of genetic diversity or physical problems.

A5.text: Single-trait breeding, breeding for only one trait over all others, can be problematic.

A6.text: Selecting for breeding animals with superior EBV in growth rate, egg, meat, milk, or wool production, or with other desirable traits has revolutionized livestock production throughout the entire world.

A7.text: Breeding the best to the best, employing a certain degree of inbreeding, considerable culling, and selection for 'superior' qualities, one could develop a bloodline superior in certain respects to the original base stock.

A8.text: In one case mentioned by the animal behaviorist Temple Grandin, roosters bred for fast growth or heavy muscles did not know how to perform typical rooster courtship dances, which alienated the roosters from hens and led the roosters to kill the hens after mating with them.

A9.text: It has been bred selectively to produce the highest yields of milk of any cow.
